moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 e6 5: the usual setup, in the Hungarian Variation of the Sicilian; for black that is... white is lacking the possibility for a swift f4...
moves.9. Nc3 dxe4 10. Nxe4 Nbc6 11. Be3 Nf5 12: too ambitious; white has no better than Qd2...
moves.12... Qb6 13. Rfd1 e5 14. d5 Nxe3 15. fx: it is hard for white, to find the best moves here; of course in the end, the d-pawn is no real threat... but black has not much so far either... Nd6 or Nc5 might be better here...
moves.19... Bh3: black completes development by connecting the rooks, whilst trading that nasty white bishop in the process; at least, that was the plan... Rad1, Bxg2+, Kxg2, is probably best for now, or Bxh3, Qxh3, Rac1...
moves.20. Bf3: this move will soon prove to be very inaccurate...
moves.20... Rac8: the start of weaving an intricate trap...
moves.21. Qxa7: greed before the fall... white had no better than Rad1, Bf5, Rf1...
moves.23. Qb5: there are many ways, to prevent the upcoming mate on h2; Re2, Rxe2, Bxe2, to name the best - but losing - one; even h4, Bxb7 is better... but white is totally oblivious...
